1.0     INTRODUCTION

This study has been prepared to evaluate the transportation impacts of the proposed Convention Center to
be located in downtown Albany, New York. The purpose of this study is to evaluate the impacts of the
proposed development on the area transportation system, including traffic operations, transit systems,
parking, and pedestrian and bike accommodations. The study also identifies alternatives and measures to
mitigate these impacts.



2.0     PROPOSED DEVELOPMENT

The proposed Convention Center is located on an approximately 16-acre site located between Hudson
Avenue, Madison Avenue, South Pearl Street and Broadway. The project site is shown on Figure 2-1.
The primary Master Plan Area is defined as the area bounded by Broadway, South Pearl Street, State
Street and Madison Avenue. This Master Plan area is also shown on Figure 2-1.


The Convention Center is proposed to be developed in two phases. Phase One will have a total building
area of 244,000 square feet. Phase Two is proposed to provide an additional 161,000 square feet of
building area, for a completed Convention Center of 405,000 square feet. The composition of this
building program is summarized in Table 2-1.

                                               Table 2-1
                                   Convention Center Building Program
                                                Phase 1          Phase 2           Total
          Leasable Area                         107,000 sf       72,000 sf        179,000 sf

          Service and Support                   100,000 sf       60,000 sf        160,000 sf

          Total Program Area                    207,000 sf      132,000 sf        339,000 sf
          Circulation, Walls, Chases, Etc.       37,000 sf       23,000 sf         66,000 sf

          Gross Building Area                  244,000 sf       155,000 sf       405,000 sf


Hotel facilities are also planned to be located on the site, to provide a total of 400 rooms.       The
employment for the Convention Center and hotel facilities is projected to be equivalent to 350 full-time
employees.


The proximity of the proposed Convention Center to the nearby Times Union Center offers an
opportunity to have coordinated activity for an additional 25,000 sq ft exhibition space at the Times

Traffic Impact Study                                                    Clough Harbour & Associates LLP
Albany Convention Center                                                                         Page 1
Union Center, which is proposed to be linked to the Convention Center by a climate-controlled overhead
pedestrian connection.


Phase One construction is anticipated to be completed in 2010, with program stabilization in 2014. The
hotel facilities are planned to be constructed in Phase One. Phase Two construction would be constructed
some time after 2014, based on a future assessment of market conditions.




Figure 2-1: Site Location Map


Traffic Impact Study                                                       Clough Harbour & Associates LLP
Albany Convention Center                                                                            Page 2
3.0     EXISTING CONDITIONS
3.1     Study Area

The study area for the project includes intersections surrounding the site and key intersections in the area
that may be impacted by the estimated site traffic. The study area intersections are as follows:


            ·   Broadway & State Street
            ·   Broadway, Broadway-Quay Street Connector & Water Street
            ·   Broadway & Hudson Avenue
            ·   Broadway & Division Street
            ·   Madison Avenue, Broadway & I-787 Southbound Ramps
            ·   Madison Avenue & Green Street
            ·   Pearl Street & Madison Avenue
            ·   Pearl Street & Empire State Plaza Arterial Eastbound Ramps
            ·   Pearl Street & Empire State Plaza Arterial Westbound Ramps
            ·   Pearl Street & Hudson Avenue
            ·   Pearl Street & State Street
            ·   Hudson Avenue & Green Street

These study intersections include locations where the local street system interfaces with the regional
highway network and the circulation streets around the project site. These study intersections are shown
in relation to the Convention Center site on Figure 3-1.

3.2     Area Roadway System

I-787 is a limited-access expressway facility providing access to downtown Albany from the region's
interstate highway system. I-787 has three through travel lanes in each direction, and connects the
downtown area to the New York State Thruway (Interchange 23) and to I-90. Access to the study area
from northbound I-787 is available from the Broadway Exit via Quay Street. Access to the study area
from southbound I-787 is available at Madison Avenue. Southbound access is also available via the
Colonie Street exit to the Water Street frontage road, which intersects with Broadway near the
Convention Center site.


Empire State Plaza (ESP) Arterial is a limited-access highway that connects I-787 and the Empire State
Plaza. The ESP Arterial also provides connection to communities of Rensselaer and East Greenbush via
the Dunn Memorial Bridge (US Routes 9 & 20). The Empire State Plaza Arterial is a divided highway



Traffic Impact Study                                                       Clough Harbour & Associates LLP
Albany Convention Center                                                                            Page 3
with two travel lanes in each direction. The posted speed limit on this roadway is 55 mph. Within the
project study area, the ESP Arterial is an elevated highway, with ramp connections to South Pearl Street.


Broadway is a north-south principal urban arterial that extends from the Port of Albany to the north city
boundary with Menands. The section of Broadway between State Street and Water Street/Quay Street
Connector intersection has two lanes for each direction of traffic. On-street parking is also provided on
both sides of the street. The section of Broadway from Water Street to Madison Avenue is one-way
southbound and has three travel lanes. Parking is not permitted on either side of the street in this one-way
section.




Figure 3-1: Study Intersections

Traffic Impact Study                                                       Clough Harbour & Associates LLP
Albany Convention Center                                                                            Page 4
Madison Avenue is US Route 20, which is an east-west principal urban arterial roadway that provides
access into the vicinity of the Empire State Plaza from I-787. Madison Avenue is a two-way roadway
with adjacent parking on both sides of the streets. Madison Avenue is a four-lane divided roadway
between Broadway and Pearl Street. West of Pearl Street, it is two-lane road with one travel lane in each
direction. On-street parking is permitted on both sides of the street.


Pearl Street is State Route 32 and is a north-south principal urban arterial roadway. Pearl Street is
fundamentally a two-lane roadway with one travel lane in each direction, and with on-street parking. At
the study intersections, parking is restricted which creates secondary turn-lanes which are formally
delineated with pavement striping.


State Street is State Route 5 and is an east-west principal urban arterial roadway that has two travel lanes
in each direction. State Street features a center striped median from Eagle Street to Broadway. At the
signalized intersections, the median is curbed and landscaped. On-street parking is provided on both
sides of the street, with angled parking in the section between Eagle Street and Pearl Street. Left-turns are
restricted on all the approaches of the intersection of State Street and Pearl Street.


Hudson Avenue is an east-west local street that connects Pearl Street and Broadway, and forms the
northern boundary of the project site. Within the study area, Hudson Avenue has one travel lane in each
direction. On-street parking is permitted along the north side of the street between Liberty Street and
Pearl Street. This street is a main access to the Green-Hudson parking garage that is operated by the
Albany Parking Authority (APA).


Green Street is a north-south local street that runs parallel to Broadway and Pearl Streets. Green Street is
a one-way street southbound from State Street to Hamilton Street, and has one travel lane and adjacent
on-street parking on both sides of the street. The section from Hamilton Street to Madison Avenue is
two-way. The two-way section of Green Street provides access and circulation from a CDTA bus staging
area and state employee parking that are located under the ESP arterial. Green Street also provides access
to the Greyhound Bus Terminal located at Hamilton Street and Liberty Street.




Traffic Impact Study                                                          Clough Harbour & Associates LLP
Albany Convention Center                                                                               Page 5
Intersection Traffic Control:
All of the study intersections are traffic signal controlled, with the exception of Broadway and Division
Street. This intersection is unsignalized with Stop sign control on the Division Street approach. The
traffic signals in the study area are managed and maintained by a combination of City and State agencies.
The maintenance/ownership jurisdiction of these signals is as follows:


                                   Traffic Signal Maintenance Jurisdiction

        City of Albany                        Pearl Street & State Street

        New York State                        Pearl Street & Hudson Avenue

                                              Pearl Street, Hamilton Street & ESP Westbound Ramp

                                              Broadway, Madison Avenue & I-787 Southbound Ramps

3.4     Parking

The public parking supply within Albany's downtown provides 9,366 off-street parking spaces and 1,948
on-street parking spaces. Most on-street parking spaces are metered, limiting parking to one hour or two
hours to encourage turnover of the most convenient downtown parking. There are a few 20-minute
meters at high turnover locations. Longer-term meters are located on streets fringing the downtown core.
The metered on-street parking spaces are managed using a "Cash-key" debit system as well as accepting
coin payments.


The Albany Parking Authority (APA) operates three multi-level parking garages in the downtown area:
the Green-Hudson Garage, the Columbia Street Garage, and the Quackenbush Square Garage. These
three facilities provide approximately 2,650 parking spaces. The Green-Hudson Garage, which has a
900-car capacity, is located along the north side of Hudson Avenue, immediately adjacent to the
Convention Center site. The other two APA-operated garages are located outside the project study area.
The approximate walking distance between the project site and these other two garages are:

        Columbia Street Garage:          2,250 feet
        Quackenbush Garage:              3,250 feet

The remaining public parking is provided in lots managed by private operators or other public agencies
(such as the visitors parking at the ESP operated by NYSOGS). Figure 3-3 shows the primary off-street
parking facilities within the vicinity of the Convention Center.


Albany Parking Authority data shows that there are also 12,371 off-street parking spaces in
private/restricted facilities. These facilities are available only to permitted employees or customers of a
business or institution.

An inventory of the existing public and private parking within the immediate area of the Convention
Center site was compiled from the Albany Parking Authority, the New York State Office of General
Services and from field reconnaissance. Based on this inventory, 720 on-street and off-street parking
spaces were identified within the general boundaries of the Convention Center site. The New York State
Office of General Services (NYSOGS) also maintains parking facilities for state employees beneath the
elevated section of the ESP Arterial adjacent to the project site. There are 728 parking spaces in this area
bounded by Madison Avenue, Broadway, Pearl Street and Green Street.



Traffic Impact Study                                                       Clough Harbour & Associates LLP
Albany Convention Center                                                                            Page 9
Figure 3-3: Existing Off-Street Parking Facilities


The average monthly fees for public parking are $137.05 for Garage parking and $95.78 for surface lot
parking. The average daily fees are $11.75 for Garage parking and $7.00 for parking in surface lots
parking.


Subscription rates for monthly parking in the public lots are generally high, and in some cases, they
exceed the capacity of the facility, consistent with industry practice. However, because of normal
variations in use by subscription holders, spaces within the public lots are usually available for transient
daytime use during weekday business hours to meet current daily parking demand. According to the
Albany Parking Authority, there is available capacity for additional monthly subscriptions in the Green-
Hudson Garage (75 spaces) and the Quackenbush Garage (320 spaces).


The existing public parking supply has significant reserve capacity for current evening and weekend
parking demand.


Traffic Impact Study                                                       Clough Harbour & Associates LLP
Albany Convention Center                                                                          Page 10
3.5     Transit Service

Transit services within the project area include public transit operated by the Capital District
Transportation Authority (CDTA) and private intracity bus carriers such as Greyhound and Adirondack
Trailways. The project site is a central hub for both the inter-city and intra-city transit operations. The
Greyhound Bus Station is located at 34 Hamilton Street, within the boundaries of the project site. This
site is strategically located for the private carrier bus companies to provide convenient access to their
client base and for efficient access to interstate routes.



3.5.1   Public Transit

The Capital District Transportation Authority (CDTA) is the region's public transportation provider. The
CDTA operates approximately 60 bus routes throughout the region, which include local and express
services, and serves 150,000 passengers per week. More than half of these routes include service to the
study area, with approximately 750 buses travelling through the project site each weekday. Figure 3-4
below shows CDTA's route map for downtown Albany.


CDTA is currently progressing an initiative to implement a regional Bus Rapid Transit (BRT) system.
The initial implementation of this high-performance transit service is focused on the NY Route 5 corridor
between downtown Schenectady and downtown Albany. The Albany Convention Center site is in the
vicinity of the planned Albany terminus of this BRT route.


                                                                 CDTA operates a bus staging area
                                                                 located beneath the Empire State Plaza
                                                                 Arterial, west of Green Street.       The
                                                                 primary use of this area is for bus
                                                                 layovers/schedule synchronization and
                                                                 for driver breaks.     Entrance to this
                                                                 facility is provided from Madison
                                                                 Avenue west of Green Street, and the
                                                                 buses exit onto Green Street near the
                                                                 intersection of Green Street, Dallius
                                                                 Street and Liberty Street. This staging
                                                                 area is shown on Figure 3-5.

Traffic Impact Study                                                      Clough Harbour & Associates LLP

Traffic Impact Study                      Clough Harbour & Associates LLP
Albany Convention Center                                         Page 13
3.5.2   Private Transit Carriers

                                   The primary private transit carriers serving downtown
                                   Albany are Greyhound and Adirondack Trailways.
                                   These carriers share the terminal facilities of the
                                   Greyhound Station at 34 Hamilton Street, along with
                                   other carriers, such as Bonanza and Peter Pan.


                                   Albany serves as a terminus stop for Greyhound routes
                                   as well as being an intermediate stop along other route
                                   destinations (e.g., New York City-to-Montreal or
                                   Buffalo-to-Boston).       Because     of    these   service
                                   characteristics, Greyhound provides on-site fueling and
                                   maintenance for their vehicles. Luggage handling and
                                   package service functions also affect their on-site
                                   operating requirements. Greyhound has approximately
                                   40 buses moving through the Albany terminal on an
                                   average weekday.


                                   Adirondack Trailways operates approximately 20 buses
                                   in and out of Albany on a daily basis. Albany is a route
                                   terminus for Adirondack Trailways; they do not have
                                   through operations to other destinations. Because of this
                                   characteristic, they are able to remotely-locate their fleet
                                   maintenance and bus storage facilities, which are located
                                   on Broadway south of the study site near the Port of
                                   Albany.     Figure 3-5 shows the location of the
                                   Greyhound bus station and maintenance facilities.




Traffic Impact Study                                         Clough Harbour & Associates LLP
Albany Convention Center                                                            Page 14
3.6     Pedestrians and Bicyclists


The project area is located within the urban downtown core
of the City. The pedestrian and bicycle accommodations are
typical of this urban setting. Sidewalks are provided on both
sides of all the streets within the study area, with marked
crosswalks    and      pedestrian   pushbuttons/indications    at
signalized intersections.


Bicyclists share the travel lanes with motor vehicles ­ there
are no designated bike lanes within the study area.
However, the New York State Department of Transportation
maintains    two       signed,   on-road   bicycle   routes   for
experienced cyclists within the study area: Bike Route 5 and
Bike Route 9. These designated bike touring routes are
shown on Figure 3-6.




The Convention Center site is near the Corning Preserve Bike-Hike trail along the Hudson River, which is
part of the 35-mile Mohawk-Hudson trail network. Access to this trail system is available from the Quay
Street underpass at Broadway. This trail is also shown on Figure 3-6.


                                                              CDTA also provides bike racks on their fleet
                                                              vehicles which promotes an integrated multi-
                                                              modal transportation system.   Bikeable Buses
                                                              are provided at regular intervals on all CDTA
                                                              routes.




CDTA Bus with Bike Rack
Source: www.cdtc.org


Traffic Impact Study                                                         Clough Harbour & Associates LLP
Albany Convention Center                                                                            Page 15
Figure 3-6: Bike Touring Routes




Traffic Impact Study              Clough Harbour & Associates LLP
Albany Convention Center                                 Page 16
4.0     PROJECTED TRAFFIC

The full buildout of the site is expected to be completed by 2010. The year 2014 is projected to be the
year of stabilization of event schedules and activities. The year 2014 consequently was selected to
represent the design horizon for evaluating the impact of the Convention Center. Traffic volumes for this
design year include traffic associated with general background changes in traffic flow due to area-wide
socio-economic factors, and the new site traffic generated by the Convention Center and Hotel.



4.1     Non-Site Background Traffic


In order to evaluate the traffic impacts of the Convention Center project in the context of background
conditions in the future year of stabilization, No-Build traffic volumes were estimated for the 2014
planning horizon. Based on a review of historical traffic volumes on the area roadways, and regional
travel demand information obtained from CDTC, an annual growth rate of 0.5% was applied to the
existing volumes to estimate the future No-Build traffic volumes in the study area. The 2014 No-Build
AM and PM peak hour traffic volumes are shown on Figure 4-1.



4.2     Site Traffic

To evaluate the future impacts of the proposed Convention Center and Hotel facilities on the
transportation system, an estimate of the trip generating potential of the site was calculated. This estimate
included considerations of the time of day when peak trips are likely to occur, mode distributions and
arrival/departure patterns. The estimated site traffic also considered the anticipated types and frequency
of events to be held at the proposed facility as identified in the market studies completed for the project.



4.2.1                Trip Generation


        4.2.1.1      Employees

The Convention Center and Hotel are estimated to have 350 full-time equivalent employees. A review of
US Census journey-to-work data for service-related occupations in the Capital Region shows that these
trips will typically occur at times outside of the conventional commuter peak hours of adjacent street

traffic or the peak hours of site activity. The census data also indicates that this employment group has a
high percentage of transit, walk/bike and ride-share trip modes, accounting for approximately 55% of
these work trips. Based on these factors, it is concluded that the trips generated by employees will not
have a significant impact on traffic operations and are consequently not considered for further analysis.



        4.2.1.2      Service/Support Delivery

Traffic generated by the project includes deliveries of supplies and equipment to support the
administrative and catering needs of the Convention Center and Hotel. These deliveries also typically
occur outside of normal peak hour periods and are randomly distributed throughout the day. These
deliveries will be consistent with the other vendor deliveries that occur throughout the downtown and will
not have a significant impact on traffic operations.


Convention Events will generate tractor-trailer truck trips associated with the set-up and take-down of the
exhibition. It is estimated that a full exhibition at the Convention Center will use 30 trucks for the set-up
and take-down of the event. The site concept includes provision for 9 loading docks to the exhibition
space, which would produce about 3-4 turnovers of trucks for the set-up and take-down processes. Based
on an estimated one-hour loading period, the set-up and take down for a capacity exhibition would each
take 4-5 hours to complete, and generate 15-20 truck trips during the hour of peak delivery (includes trips
entering and exiting). It is noted that this is not a daily activity, since it only occurs at the beginning and
end of each event. Smaller conferences and trade shows would generate fewer trucks. The times of day
that truck deliveries would occur will vary based on the scheduling of events. However, these truck flows
would not occur concurrently with the peak traffic generated by event attendees since they are associated
with pre-event and post-event activities.


For events that also utilize space at the Times Union Center, another 9 trucks is anticipated for set-up/take
down. This type of activity already normally occurs for events at the Times Union Center and the Times
Union Center has its own accommodation for truck staging and deliveries. While the Convention Center
will present an opportunity to increase the number of event days for the Times Union Center, the number
of trucks generated during peak hours will not be significantly different from what occurs currently at the
Times Union Center.




Traffic Impact Study                                                         Clough Harbour & Associates LLP
Albany Convention Center                                                                            Page 19
           4.2.1.3      Event Patrons

The market studies for the Convention Center identified that the design condition would have an average
daily attendance of 2,200 people for a convention-style event, where all attendees would essentially stay
for the duration of the event. It is estimated that 90% of the annual tradeshow and convention demand
would be at or below this design attendance. These events would typically occur on weekdays during
normal business hours and would consequently have the greatest potential for impact to peak-hour traffic
operations. Other events at the Convention Center, such as a consumer show, would have greater
potential daily attendance. For these events, people would arrive and depart randomly throughout the
event so that the hourly travel demand would not be as significant as for a conference event. These
consumer shows also typically occur during weekend or evening periods when background traffic levels
are low.


Trip Generation published by the Institute of Transportation Engineers (ITE) is an industry-standard
resource for estimating the traffic generated by various types of land uses. However, trip data is not
available in this reference document for conference/convention facilities. Consequently, assumptions
pertaining to factors such as attendance characteristics, conference operations, modal distributions and
vehicle occupancies were used to develop the estimated trips generated during the weekday AM and PM
peak hours of adjacent street traffic for convention events.


Modal distribution of the event site traffic can vary significantly by the type of event and the geographic
extent of the participants/attendees. The accessibility of the project site by local transit services with
linkages to the Albany International Airport and CDTA-Rensselaer rail station, along with the downtown
urban context of the site, indicates a strong potential for access to the site by transit, taxi or by walking
(from area hotels). For the purposes of this analysis, it is estimated that 25% of the convention attendees
would use transit or walk to the site. This represents 550 convention attendees using non-auto modes for
the design event.


Documents published by the Eno Foundation1 and ITE2 cite vehicle occupancy rates for special events,
including events at conference centers, to be between 2.1 and 4.0 people per vehicle. However, this data
includes spectator events that would have higher vehicle occupancy than would be anticipated for a
convention event in Albany. Considering these vehicle occupancy characteristics and the range of


1
    Parking, Eno Foundation, 1990 and Parking for Institutions and Special Events, Eno Foundation, 1982
2
    Traffic Considerations for Special Events, Institute of Transportation Engineers, 1976

Traffic Impact Study                                                            Clough Harbour & Associates LLP
Albany Convention Center                                                                               Page 20
functions anticipated for the facility, an average vehicle occupancy of 1.5 people per vehicle was used to
estimate the trips associated with convention events.


Based on these factors of mode choice and vehicle occupancy, it is estimated that the design convention
event will generate approximately 1,100 vehicle trips. These trips were correlated to hourly distribution
factors for the weekday AM and PM periods to identify the amount of traffic generated by the design
convention event during the highest hour.       Based on these considerations, it is estimated that the
Convention Center will generate 550 vehicle trips during the weekday AM peak hour and 735 vehicle
trips during the weekday PM peak hour for the design convention event. Table 4-1 provides a summary
of the estimated entering and exiting distribution of site traffic during these peak hours. The supporting
calculations of these trip estimates are provided in the Appendix.




                                               Table 4-1
                                     Peak Hour Site Generated Trips
                                   Design Condition Conference Event

                                                        Weekday      Weekday
                                  Direction             AM Peak      PM Peak
                                                         Hour         Hour

                                    Enter                495           75
                                     Exit                 55          660
                                    Total                550          735




It is noted that the Phase Two expansion of the Convention Center will allow for larger events to be held
at the site than in Phase One. However, these larger events would not represent a design condition due to
their infrequent occurrence in terms of the number of annual event days. Further, these larger events are
likely to involve the use of lodging and/or parking resources that are located outside of the downtown
district, such that shuttle transportation and other special event management strategies would be deployed.
Therefore, the design attendance event of 2,200 people applies to both the Phase One and Phase Two
conditions.




Traffic Impact Study                                                        Clough Harbour & Associates LLP
Albany Convention Center                                                                           Page 21
4.2.2   Trip Distribution

The trip distribution patterns for the traffic generated by Convention Center events were estimated from
existing peak hour traffic patterns in the vicinity of the site and considering the proximity of the site to the
regional transportation network and modal facilities (airport, bus and rail). Based on these considerations,
it is estimated that the Convention Center traffic will have the following distribution:

             35%     to/from I-787 north
             30%     to/from I-787 south
             10%     to/from US Rte 20 east
              5%     to/from US Route 20 west
              5%     to/from Route 32 north
              5%     to/from Route 32 south
             10%     to/from NY Route 5 west



Trip assignments to the study area roadways also considered the changes in the street network associated
with the proposed Convention Center site. These trip assignments are shown on Figure 4-2 for the
weekday AM and PM peak hours.



4.3     Build Condition Traffic Volumes

The Convention Center Build Condition will cause a redistribution of non-site traffic in the study area due
to the displacement of the existing on-site parking supply and from changes to the street network from the
site development. The anticipated changes in non-site traffic flow for the 2014 design horizon are shown
on Figure 4-3.


The 2014 No-Build volumes were adjusted to reflect these changes in non-site traffic flow and then
combined with the Convention Center site trips to produce the 2014 Build Condition volumes for the AM
and PM peak hours. These Build Condition volumes are presented on Figure 4-4.

                 5.0              TRANSPORTATION ANALYSIS


                 5.1              Site Access

                 The specific details of site planning and design have not been completed at this stage of the planning
                 process for the project. However, the project site will continue to have access to Hudson Avenue and to
                 Madison Avenue via Green Street. For the purposes of evaluating the traffic impacts of the project, it is
                 assumed that full access to the project will be available to site traffic from both of these streets. Truck
                 deliveries to the site will be provided from Madison Avenue at Green Street to access the Convention
                 Center and Hotel loading and service facilities.




                 5.2              Site Parking Demand

                 Activities and events at the Albany Convention Center will generate a range of parking demand that will
                 vary based on the specific events and the geographic area from which participants are drawn. It is
                 anticipated that locally-based events will generate a higher parking demand ratio per attendee than larger
                 regional or national events, since these larger events would have a higher proportion of participants
                 arriving by rail, bus or air, with transit or taxi service to the site.


                                       Parking Demand Distribution                       Market projections of the range of activities and
                                                                                         attendance for the Convention Center indicate
                          150
                                                                                         that the daily parking demand will range from
                          125

Center at this level will accommodate the projected attendance representing a midweek design event of
2,200 people.


Parking for the hotel facilities is proposed to be provided at a ratio of 1-space per room, resulting in 400
parking spaces for this use. It is noted that the estimates of the convention center parking needs includes
assumptions regarding the interaction of the hotel and the convention center.


Based on these analyses, 1,100 total parking spaces are proposed to be provided on-site to accommodate
the projected parking demand of the Convention Center and Hotel facilities. Parking accommodations for
special events with higher parking demand are proposed to be accommodated through use of other
downtown parking supplies, as available (i.e., in the case of events occurring on weekends where there is
abundant parking supply in the downtown) or through the use of remote parking with shuttle service. The
Port of Albany has facilities available to accommodate special event parking which have been used for
special events at other downtown venues, such as the Times Union Center.




5.3     Capacity and Level of Service

The operating conditions of transportation facilities are evaluated based on the relationship of existing or
projected traffic volumes to the theoretical capacity of the highway facility. Various factors affect
capacity including traffic volume, travel speed, roadway geometry, grade, number and width of travel
lanes and intersection control. The current standards for evaluating capacity and operating conditions are
contained in the 2000 Highway Capacity Manual, published by the Transportation Research Board. The
procedures describe operating conditions in terms of Level of Service (LOS). In general, "A" represents
the best operating condition and "F" represents the worst. Level of service "D" or better typically
represents acceptable operating conditions.      Descriptions of LOS and the associated performance
measures set forth in the HCM 2000 are provided in Appendix B.


To determine the impact of the proposed project on the operations of the adjacent transportation system,
traffic operations were analyzed for the AM and PM peak hours for the following conditions:


                           ·   2007 Existing Conditions
                           ·   2014 No-Build Conditions
                           ·   2014 Build Conditions


Traffic Impact Study                                                       Clough Harbour & Associates LLP
Albany Convention Center                                                                          Page 27
The traffic operations within the study area for these conditions are summarized in Table 5-1 for the AM
peak hour and in Table 5-2 for the PM peak hour at the end of this section, and are described below. The
computation worksheet summaries are provided in Appendix D.



5.3.1   Existing Operations


The operating conditions of the study intersections were analyzed using the existing traffic volumes,
roadway geometry, signal timings and intersection control for the weekday AM and PM peak hours. As
indicated in Tables 5-1 and 5-2, the roadway system provides generally high levels of service throughout
the study area, with overall intersection Levels of Service (LOS) that are LOS C or better during both
peak hours in most cases.         The notable exceptions to this level of mobility are at the following
intersections:


                    ·      Broadway, Madison Avenue and I-787 Southbound Ramps
                    ·      Madison Avenue and Green Street
                    ·      Broadway and Division Street

Broadway, Madison Avenue & I-787 SB Ramp Intersection:            This intersection is a connection of the
local street system to the regional interstate highway network, and is one of the focal points of traffic
entering and exiting the downtown area. Peak hour operations here are symptomatic of this gateway
characteristic and are consistent with the operations of other gateway connections in the City between the
local and regional roadways during peak hours. Although the operations analyses show that the overall
intersection operates at overall LOS B during the AM peak hour, vehicle queues on the I-787 ramp
approach to the intersection can be highly variable and sometimes extend beyond the existing available
storage. This condition does not occur over extended periods of time and does not seriously affect the
mobility of traffic moving through the area. The LOS E condition on the low-volume northbound
approach of Broadway in the AM peak hour is a result of the allocation of signal time to give priority to
the major traffic movements, and is not indicative of significant congestion on this approach.


The overall operation during the PM peak hour is LOS D, which is within an acceptable design service
threshold for urban conditions.

Madison Avenue & Green Street Intersection: The intersection of Madison Avenue and Green Street
operates at an acceptable overall LOS D during the PM peak hour, but the southbound approach of Green
Street operates at LOS F. This condition is associated with the delay for traffic on southbound Green

Traffic Impact Study                                                      Clough Harbour & Associates LLP
Albany Convention Center                                                                         Page 28
Street exiting the parking facilities in this area.     The traffic signal operates in a two-phase cycle,
alternating between Madison Avenue traffic and Green Street traffic. This contributes to delay for the
high volume of left-turn traffic from Green Street onto Madison Avenue headed toward the ramps to I-
787. The other intersection approaches all operate at LOS A or LOS B. The LOS F for the southbound
approach could be improved by providing an extended green period for southbound traffic with a
protected left-turn phase. The operations with this improvement would be LOS C for the southbound
approach, and the overall intersection would operate at LOS B.


Broadway & Division Street Intersection: The "T" intersection of Division Street and Broadway is
unsignalized, with a STOP sign on the Division Street approach. The analysis shows that Level of
Service F conditions are experienced for traffic on the Division Street approach during the PM peak hour.
However, the traffic volume on this approach is relatively low, and a review of other performance
measures such as the ratio of volume-to-capacity and the length of queues indicate that this intersection
operates within acceptable ranges. As noted at the other intersections in the study area, the period of
congested operations typically occurs for one hour or less such that the delay and congestion is not
excessive and does not significantly affect mobility.



5.3.2   2014 No-Build Operations


The projected general changes in traffic flow in the 2014 design year that are not associated with the
Convention Center will not have a significant impact on traffic operations in the study area. The overall
levels of service will continue to be consistent with the existing operations as described above. As shown
in Tables 5-1 and 5-2, it is noted that the LOS for two locations will change as result of the projected
background growth:


        Pearl Street & State Street: southbound approach changes from LOS D to LOS E in AM peak
        hour
        Broadway & Madison Avenue: northbound approach changes from LOS C to LOS E in PM peak
        hour

The change in LOS for the southbound approach of Pearl Street at State Street is primarily associated
with the signal timing priority given to the coordinated traffic flow on State Street, which operates at LOS
A/B. The overall intersection will continue to operate at LOS C. Minor adjustments to the signal timing
plans could be implemented as part of the City's routine and ongoing signal system management, as
appropriate to adjust for these minor changes in traffic flows and operations.

Traffic Impact Study                                                       Clough Harbour & Associates LLP
Albany Convention Center                                                                          Page 29
The change in LOS for the northbound approach of Broadway at Madison Avenue is again the result of
signal timing priorities at the intersection, as discussed previously regarding existing system operations.
The overall intersection operations will be LOS D, similar to existing operations, and no improvements
are indicated.


The operations for the 2014 No-Build condition are summarized in Tables 5-1 and 5-2 for the AM peak
hour and PM peak hour, respectively.




5.3.3   2014 Build Operations


The analyses of 2014 design year operations with the Convention Center traffic and changes in traffic
patterns associated with the site shows that the traffic operations at the study intersections will be
consistent with the operations of the No-Build operations. Locations where changes in the intersection
level of service will occur are noted in Table 5-3.




                                                   Table 5-3
                                           Level of Service Impacts
                      Location                     Peak Hour                 LOS impact

         Broadway & State Street               AM Peak Hour        change from LOS C to LOS D


         Broadway & Hudson Avenue              AM Peak Hour        change from LOS A to LOS B
                                               PM Peak Hour        change from LOS B to LOS C


         Broadway & Division Street            PM Peak Hour        change from LOS E to LOS F*


         Green Street & Madison Avenue         PM Peak Hour        change from LOS D to LOS E

         * Stop sign minor approach of unsignalized intersection




As noted in Table 5-3, most of the changes in level of service resulting from the Convention Center
project are not significant, and the overall levels of service will be within ranges that are consistent with
design objectives for urban areas. The change in level of service at the intersection of Division Street and
Broadway pertains to the stop-sign controlled minor approach movements. This operation is consistent


Traffic Impact Study                                                        Clough Harbour & Associates LLP
Albany Convention Center                                                                           Page 30
with other unsignalized intersections in the downtown core during peak hours and pertains to a relatively
low volume approach (less than 60 vehicles per hour). A review of other performance measures such as
the volume-to-capacity ratio and queues indicate that the intersection will operate acceptably and that no
improvements are indicated.


The change in level of service at the intersection of Green Street and Madison Avenue is associated with
the same issue described for the existing condition on the southbound approach of Green Street. With the
recommended improvement to provide an extension of greentime for this approach (for traffic exiting
from the Bus Station and Convention Center), this intersection will operate at the same level of service as
in the No-Build Condition; the southbound approach will operate at LOS C and the overall intersection
will operate at LOS B.


These analyses indicate that the transportation system will continue to provide acceptable levels of service
and mobility through the study area. Minor adjustments to signal timing plans could also be implemented
as part of the City's routine and ongoing signal system management, to optimize the traffic flow as
appropriate to adjust for future changes in traffic flow patterns.
