Traffic Impact Study                                                                Clough Harbour & Associates LLP
Albany Convention Center                                                                                   Page 33
6.0     IMPACTS AND MITIGATION

This section summarizes the evaluations of the impacts of the Convention Center project on the various
components of the study area transportation system, including traffic circulation, traffic operations,
parking, transit, and pedestrian/bicycle facilities. This section also briefly describes the alternatives
considered to address the project's impacts and identifies recommended improvements.



6.1     Traffic Circulation

The Phase One development of the Convention Center will remove sections of the existing street grid
within the study site, including all or part of Dallius Street, Green Street, Hamilton Street and Division
Street. These are local streets that provide access/circulation to the existing surface parking facilities in
the area and do not have a network-level significance for traffic movement through the downtown.
However, elements of this street grid are currently used as part of the service route for CDTA transit and
by private-carrier buses. The impacts of the changes to the street grid on these transit operations are
described in more detail in subsection 6.4 ­ Transit.


Access to the parking facilities of the Key Bank Building at 66 South Peal Street (corner of Hudson
Avenue and South Pearl Street) may be impacted by the specifics of the site design for the ACC and will
need to be addressed as site design is progressed. Similarly, the service access for truck deliveries to this
building will also be impacted and will need to be addressed in the site design.


The changes in the street network and site design will also affect access to the existing parking area under
the ESP arterial between Green Street and Pearl Street, if this area continues to maintain its current use
for state employee parking. However, there is a potential that this space will be incorporated into the
Convention Center project for ancillary uses such as truck staging and site parking. In either case, the
access and circulation to this area will be integrated with the site design.


The street network provides for emergency access and evacuation from Hudson Avenue and via Green
Street to Madison Avenue. Emergency access is also available to Broadway from Division Street. It is
recommended that the site plan design include connectivity suitable for emergency vehicles to access the



Traffic Impact Study                                                           Clough Harbour & Associates LLP
Albany Convention Center                                                                              Page 34
Green Street area of the site via the Division Street-to-Hamilton Street corridor to provide system
redundancy for emergency access.



6.2     Traffic Operations

As discussed in Section 5, the development of the Convention center will cause a redistribution of
existing traffic because of the changes in the street grid associate with the Convention Center facilities.
The analysis of traffic operations with these changes and with the additional traffic generated by the
Convention Center shows that the project will not have a significant impact on traffic operations. Levels
of service at the study intersections will continue to be within thresholds that are consistent with the
mobility objectives for this urban area, with normal ongoing system management to optimize traffic
signal timings.


Signal improvements are recommended at the intersection of Green Street and Madison Avenue to be
able to extend the greentime provided to southbound traffic on Green Street. This will involve equipment
modification/replacement to provide the signal displays and vehicle detection to implement this
improvement. This improvement would address existing congestion during the PM peak hour and is also
recommended to facilitate egress from the Convention Center parking during peak periods.




6.3     Parking

The Convention Center and Hotel project will generate a design parking demand for 1,100 parking
spaces. The Phase One development of the Albany Convention Center will also permanently displace
720 parking spaces, including 71 on-street metered spaces and 649 off-street spaces. These spaces
include general transient and monthly permit users. The Greyhound Bus Company also maintains a lot
for bus parking and employee parking in the area to be occupied by the Convention Center. This lot
typically stores 10-15 buses and parking for approximately 25 employees.


The area adjacent to the Convention Center site, beneath the elevated section of the ESP arterial, provides
730 parking spaces for state employees. The NYS Office of General Services (NYSOGS) manages these
parking spaces through an agreement with the NYS Department of Transportation (NYSDOT), and


Traffic Impact Study                                                       Clough Harbour & Associates LLP
Albany Convention Center                                                                          Page 35
provides a shuttle service to the Empire State Plaza for employees using this parking. It is intended that
this parking be relocated to other proposed facilities, which would enable this space under the ESP
arterial to be used for enhanced transit staging/parking, relocated Greyhound parking and for various
Convention Center-related uses such as charter bus parking, and truck/equipment staging.

This plan will result in the permanent displacement of 1,450 parking spaces. Combined with the new
parking demand generated by the Convention Center and Hotel, results in a total parking need of 2,550
parking spaces.


Various options and alternatives were explored to address the parking demand, including opportunities for
transit/ride-share incentives to reduce parking demand and for new parking structures.               Although
strategies to promote increased transit ridership and other modes are an important element of the regional
congestion management plan, it was found that the mechanisms and local issues to accomplish this are
beyond the scope and control of the Convention Center action. It is noted that the parking demand
assessment for the Convention Center accounted for the anticipated mode share of transit riders, walkers,
etc, recognizing its urban location and strategic accessibility to transit and other transportation modes and
services. The feasible options that were identified to meet the site parking demand and the displaced
parking impacts of the project include the following:

        ·   New on-site parking facilities for Convention Center and Hotel
        ·   Construct new surface parking lots along Church Street under the elevated portion of I-787,
            south of the site
        ·   Leverage available subscription capacity at APA Green-Hudson and Quackenbush garages
        ·   Construct an additional parking level on the existing Green-Hudson garage
        ·   Retain a portion of the existing parking beneath the ESP arterial


Together, these options would create approximately 2,555 parking spaces, which would accommodate the
displaced parking and the new Convention Center/Hotel parking demand. This parking mitigation plan is
summarized in Table 6-1.


The elements of the parking mitigation plan to provide parking through leverage of the reserve capacity of
the APA Quackenbush Garage and to provide surface parking along Church Street would require
incentives to counteract the distance of these facilities to the activity centers served by the parking that is
currently located on the Convention Center site.




Traffic Impact Study                                                         Clough Harbour & Associates LLP
Albany Convention Center                                                                            Page 36
                                                     Table 6-1
                                             Parking Impact Mitigation
                                                                                   New Parking
                       Location                            Option
                                                                                (number of spaces)
                                                 New Convention Center &
                Convention Center Site                                                 1,100
                                                      Hotel Parking
                  Church Street /I-787           Construct new surface lots              550
                                                    Leverage Available
                                                                                          75
              APA Green-Hudson Parking                    Reserve
                      Garage                     Construct additional parking
                                                                                         230
                                                            level
                                                    Leverage Available
              APA Quackenbush Garage                                                     400
                                                          Reserve
              ESP Arterial Surface Parking       Existing Parking Retainage              200

                                         Total                                         2,555




The APA Quackenbush Garage is located near the intersection of Broadway and Clinton Avenue,
approximately ¾ mile north of the project site. This garage is about a 15-20 minute walk to the project
site and to employment destinations along the State Street corridor. This distance is too far from the
Convention Center to be accessible and would be a competitive disadvantage for attracting events. This
distance is also further than is normally accepted by commuters for outdoor/uncovered walking distances
between parking and employment. However, the Quackenbush Garage is served by seven CDTA transit
routes that also serve the State Street corridor. If incentivized to compensate for the added trip cost and
transfer time, this transit service could enhance the serviceability of the Quackenbush Garage for workers
to access the State Street corridor whose parking is displaced at the Convention Center site.


The proposed Church Street/I-787 parking is also remote to the Convention Center site, making it
infeasible for general Convention Center use. This site is proposed to be used to relocate the state
employee parking displaced from the OGS lots under the ESP arterial. Shuttle services that are currently
provided to transport employees to the Empire State Plaza can be easily re-routed to service these new
lots. The location of the Church Street/I-787 lots also has convenient access to I-787 and the same street
network as available at the existing OGS lots. The estimated capacity of the Church Street/I-787 facility
is 180 spaces less than would be OGS parking displaced at the Convention Center. These lost spaces will
be recovered in the plan to accommodate the other displaced parking spaces.



Traffic Impact Study                                                            Clough Harbour & Associates LLP
Albany Convention Center                                                                               Page 37
6.4     Transit

Phase One of the Convention Center will have a significant impact on existing CDTA public transit
circulation and operations as a result of the changes to the street network necessitated by the Convention
Center building footprint. The primary impacts to CDTA's system are: [1] access and function of the
existing CDTA bus staging area, and [2] route circulation and service to Broadway northbound.



6.4.1   CDTA Bus Staging


As noted in previous sections, CDTA maintains a central staging area for their buses in a lot located
underneath the elevated section of Empire State Plaza arterial, adjacent to the Convention Center site.
The buses enter this lot from Madison Avenue west of Green Street and exit to Green Street west of
Dallius Street. The exit from the existing staging area will directly conflict with the truck service
facilities for the Convention Center.     This conflict will contribute to significant problems for bus
maneuvers leaving the staging area, which will also affect service times and present scheduling issues for
CDTA. Investigations of options to address this impact considered alternatives to relocate the staging
area to other locations within the site area and other off-site locations. From these investigations, and in
consultation with CDTA, NYSOGS and NYSDOT staff, a preferred alternative was identified to move
the bus staging to a new area under the ESP arterial east of Green Street. The relocated bus staging area
is also proposed to be expanded to accommodate the displaced Greyhound bus parking and to provide a
parking/staging area for charter buses serving events at the Convention Center. Access to this staging
area is recommended to be provided from Madison Avenue approximately 250-feet west of Broadway.
Egress will be provided to Liberty Street. The relocated staging area is shown on Figure 6-1.




Traffic Impact Study                                                       Clough Harbour & Associates LLP
Albany Convention Center                                                                          Page 38
Figure 6-1: Relocated Bus Staging Area

6.4.2   CDTA Route Circulation


Access to Broadway northbound is a critically important function of CDTA's route structure and rider
base. The section of Broadway near the Convention Center will also be a terminal station in their planned
Bus Rapid Transit (BRT) service along the NYS Route 5 corridor. Currently, CDTA buses use Dallius
Street and Hudson Avenue to move between their staging area under the ESP arterial and Broadway.
CDTA also has a bus stop at the Greyhound Station at the corner of Dallius Street and Hamilton Street,
along this route.


The street network that will remain after the Convention Center is built will not be suitable for bus
circulation to access Broadway because of the narrow street widths and small corner radii. Improvements
to adapt Hamilton Street, Liberty Street and Division Street to accommodate these bus movements are not
feasible due to constraints of the Convention Center footprint and surrounding buildings. CDTA staff
also expressed their concern that bus movement through the Convention Center site could negatively

Traffic Impact Study                                                     Clough Harbour & Associates LLP
Albany Convention Center                                                                        Page 39
affect their route service and travel times as a result of the increased traffic flow in the area, such that the
preferred option to address these impact issues relates to finding an alternative route for bus circulation.


The local street network in the study area is somewhat constrained by the configuration of the elevated
ESP arterial and I-787 highways and their related ramp systems. One result of this configuration is that
the section of Broadway between Water Street and Madison Avenue is designated for one-way traffic
southbound. For buses to access Broadway northbound from the study area without traveling through the
Convention Center site involves a southbound route to Quay Street and then northbound to the Broadway-
Quay Street connector at Water Street. This route is shown on Figure 6-2.




Figure 6-2: Alternate CDTA Bus Route




Traffic Impact Study                                                          Clough Harbour & Associates LLP
Albany Convention Center                                                                             Page 40
However, CDTA has calculated that this route will increase their transit operating costs by more than
$600,000 per year as a result of the additional "wheel costs" associated with this route diversion. These
"wheel costs" account for factors such as operator time, fuel costs and vehicle maintenance applied to
each trip on an annualized basis.


Another option that was considered was to convert the one-way section of Broadway to general two-way
operation to allow buses to access Broadway northbound from Madison Avenue.                 However, this
alternative was found to have a significant negative effect on traffic operations at the intersection of
Broadway, Madison Avenue and I-787 Southbound Ramps, which would contribute to increased delay
and queues on the I-787 ramp. Because of these negative operations and safety impacts, this option was
also dismissed from further consideration.


A series of additional investigations were conducted of the potential to create a new street connection
from the site to the two-way section of Broadway north of Water Street that could serve the CDTA
circulation. However, these alternatives all proved unfeasible because of impacts to existing buildings,
inadequate right-of-way and/or they were not consistent with access management best practices (which
would have a negative impact on mobility and safety on Broadway). These options were consequently
also dismissed from further consideration.


The preferred alternative that evolved from these investigations is to create a bus-only access to
Broadway from an extension of Liberty Street along the north side of the EPS arterial, and create a
contra-flow bus lane on Broadway to allow northbound bus-only movement between this access and the
Broadway-Water Street intersection. The section of Broadway between the Liberty Street extension and
Madison Avenue would remain one-way southbound so that there would not be a change in operations at
the intersection of Broadway, Madison Avenue and the I-787 Southbound ramps. This contra-flow lane
concept is illustrated on Figure 6-3.


The Liberty Street extension is proposed to be gate-controlled with secure activation by authorized
vehicles to provide access to the contra-flow lane. CDTA buses could also turn south on Broadway with
general southbound traffic as necessary. This concept will allow CDTA to efficiently maintain their route
access to Broadway and will not incur additional wheel costs from their current levels. This alternative



Traffic Impact Study                                                      Clough Harbour & Associates LLP
Albany Convention Center                                                                         Page 41
Figure 6-3: Contra-flow Bus Lane Concept


can be constructed primarily within NYSDOT right-of-way, but may also require some property
acquisition from the adjacent Holiday Inn Express.


The implementation of this access connection to Broadway will require a break-in-access authorization
from NYSDOT and from the Federal Highway Administration (FHWA) because of the terms of right-of-
way acquisition when the interstate facilities were constructed. While this is not simply a procedural


Traffic Impact Study                                                   Clough Harbour & Associates LLP
Albany Convention Center                                                                      Page 42
issue, it is anticipated that the governing authorities will support a request for break-in-access since the
break-in-access will provide a public benefit by promoting public transit operations and supporting the
overall public benefits of the Convention Center project.


The implementation of the contra-flow bus lane will require reconstruction of the section of Broadway to
provide a separating median between the southbound traffic and the northbound bus-only lane. This
median will also provide a barrier at the intersection of Pruyn Street and Broadway to maintain the
existing right-in/right-out only from Pruyn Street.     Intersection improvements at the intersection of
Broadway, Water Street and the Broadway-Quay Street connector are also recommended to modify the
geometry and signal equipment to accommodate the contra-flow bus lane, as shown in Figure 6-3.




6.4.3   Private Carriers


The Phase One construction of the Convention Center has been designed to minimize the impact to the
existing operations of the Greyhound/Trailways facilities and services. The convention center building
footprint does not encroach on the site of the existing bus station or the streets directly abutting it.
However, the project will impact the circulation route to/from Broadway via Division Street used by
many of the buses arriving from or destined to I-787 northbound.            As was noted in the previous
discussion of CDTA bus circulation (See Section 6.4.2), improvements to accommodate future bus
movements to and from Division Street from the bus station are not feasible due to constraints of the
Convention Center footprint and surrounding buildings. Alternate routes are available to these private
carriers, such as those shown on Figure 6-4. The additional distances associated with these alternative
access routes are not significant in the context of the overall route distance of these carriers and does not
have a significant impact on their "wheel costs".




Traffic Impact Study                                                       Clough Harbour & Associates LLP
Albany Convention Center                                                                          Page 43
Figure 6-4: Alternative Private Carrier Route


Improvements around the Greyhound Station will be needed to meet the access and circulation
requirements of the Greyhound bus service operations as a result of the changes in the street network
associated with the Convention Center. These improvements are to widen Hamilton Street between
Dallius Street and Liberty Street, and to increase the corner radius at Hamilton Street and Liberty Street to
accommodate a right-turn maneuver for a bus to enable package loading along the east side of the station.


The project's impact to the existing Greyhound bus and employee parking is planned to be
accommodated in the provisions made to provide transit staging under the ESP arterial, as described in
Section 6.4.1.




Traffic Impact Study                                                       Clough Harbour & Associates LLP
Albany Convention Center                                                                          Page 44
6.4.4   Intermodal Transportation Center


The site of the existing Greyhound station has been identified for possible future conversion into an
intermodal transportation center to better serve transit providers and users. Concepts for an intermodal
center at this site have been discussed for nearly thirty years. The future Phase Two expansion of the
Convention Center presents an opportunity for a collaborative effort to progress the intermodal concept
and to coordinate this with the expanded Convention Center facilities. At this time, the program and
space requirements for the intermodal facility have not been defined. These details and the similar space
configurations for Phase Two of the Convention Center will need to be evaluated in the future as these
plans advance. However, the Phase One actions to consolidate transit staging facilities under the ESP
arterial and provide access improvements to Broadway contribute positively to the process of organizing
and integrating the various transit operations which will further advance the goal of developing an
intermodal center.




6.4.5   Pedestrian and Bicycle Facilities


The site redevelopment for the Convention Center will have a positive impact on the pedestrian
environment by transforming the area from an open parking field to a vibrant urban activity center. The
project also includes streetscape improvements to strengthen the pedestrian connectivity of the site to the
Pearl Street and Broadway corridors. The recommended transit route diversions enable the Division
Street area to be redesigned to create a pedestrian-oriented corridor between the Convention Center and
Broadway.


The intersection improvements recommended for the intersection of Broadway and Water Street to
remove the free-flow southbound lane on Broadway will place all vehicle movements under signal
control, which will reduce the pedestrian-vehicle conflict areas at the intersection for access to the
Corning Preserve and Hudson River waterfront area. This improvement also provides a corner space for
landscape treatments at this gateway area of the downtown.


The reconstruction of the section of Broadway south of Water Street for the contra-flow bus lane will
potentially require the removal of some or all of the sidewalk along the east side of Broadway (adjacent to
I-787). The full extent of this impact will be determined as the design effort is progressed. This is not
anticipated to have a significant impact on pedestrian accessibility or circulation as this sidewalk does not

Traffic Impact Study                                                       Clough Harbour & Associates LLP
Albany Convention Center                                                                          Page 45
connect to anything and a continuous sidewalk is available on the west side of Broadway extending from
Madison Avenue to the downtown.


The project will not affect the existing bicycle facilities in the area and the changes in vehicle traffic will
not have an impact on the operations or function of the designated bicycle touring routes. Bicycle
facilities and amenities at the Convention Center are recommended to promote multimodal travel to the
Convention Center in conjunction with CDTA's existing Bikeable Bus program and the nearby linkage to
the Hudson-Mohawk trail system.



6.5     Special Events

The Convention Center is anticipated to periodically attract larger events than the "design" event. These
special events may require the deployment of additional short-duration transportation and parking
management strategies to accommodate the traffic generated by these events. Some examples of the
strategies that may be deployed for these special events include:


            Traveler Information
               Variable message signs
               Media announcements/communication
               Pre-event information campaigns

            Travel Demand Management
               Remote parking with transit shuttle
               Enhanced airport and train station shuttle
               Parking priorities for car-pools, etc.
               Parking pricing management
               Automobile-restricted zones
               Transit incentives
               Rideshare incentives

            Traffic Management
               Traffic responsive signal operations
               Manual intersection control
               Temporary signing and traffic control
               Temporary on-street parking restrictions
               Traffic management/enforcement patrols



The need for and development of a management plan for these special events should be determined on a
case-by-case basis due to the variability of the possible event characteristics.           The planning and
implementation of these strategies for special events will involve interagency and interjurisdiction

Traffic Impact Study                                                         Clough Harbour & Associates LLP
Albany Convention Center                                                                            Page 46
coordination.         The Capital Region Traffic Management Task Force is an existing consortium of
transportation agencies and other stakeholders that coordinate the transportation management planning
and implementation for special events in the region, including those in downtown Albany. This task
force provides the organizational framework for developing logical and consistent event management
plans, in conjunction with the event planners, to provide safe and efficient transportation operations
during these special events.



7.0        OPTIMIZED GROWTH PLAN

The Convention Center is anticipated to stimulate additional development in the study area and adjacent
sectors of the City. Assessments of the opportunities for induced growth considered a Secondary Master
Plan area that is generally within a ¾ mile radius of the Convention Center site and is bounded by the
Hudson River Waterfront, Morton Avenue, Delaware Avenue/Lark Street and Livingston Avenue.
Development associated with the Optimized Growth Plan for the secondary master plan area would create
1.76 million square feet of new commercial retail and office space and 5,600 residential units.


The potential traffic generated by this induced development was estimated using trip generation data
published by the Institute of Transportation Engineers as a basis. Table 7-1 below summarizes this trip
generation potential of the optimized growth development. As shown in Table 7-1, this new development
could generate 6,500 vehicle trips during the AM peak hour and 9,000 vehicle trips during the PM peak
hour. It is noted that this trip estimate is based on a primarily suburban, auto-oriented land use pattern,
which is not characteristic of the Master Plan area. However, these figures are useful in illustrating the
magnitude of potential impact and the importance of implementing strategies to integrate this future
development into the urban context through smart-growth urban design principles to reinforce and
strengthen multi-modal transportation opportunities.
                                                           Table 7-1
                                                   Development Trip Generation
                                                                                  AM Peak Hour                      PM Peak Hour
                                                                            Enter        Exit       Total      Enter        Exit      Total

      Residential: 5,600 Units                                                 485       2,165      2,650      2,080       1,070      3,150

      360,000 Sq Ft Retail                                                     460         290        750      1,380       1,500      2,880

      1,400,000 Sq Ft Office                                                 2,730         370      3,100         500      2,470      2,970
                                                       1
      Total Trip Generation ­ Unadjusted                                     3,675       2,825      6,500      3,960       5,040      9,000

      *1- based on auto-oriented development patterns. Does not reflect mode adjustments to reflect status quo or enhanced use of alternative
      modes such as walking, biking or transit.


Traffic Impact Study                                                                                   Clough Harbour & Associates LLP
Albany Convention Center                                                                                                      Page 47
As an example, Albany's Center Square neighborhood features mixed land uses in densities that make
walking, bicycling and transit feasible and attractive alternatives to driving. US Census data indicates
that less than half (45 percent) of the journey-to-work trips originating in the Center Square neighborhood
are made by automobile; with walking, biking and transit accounting for 50 percent of these trips and
work-at-home comprising another 5 percent. In contrast, more than 70 percent of the work-based trips for
residents of the City as a whole are currently made by automobile.


The revitalization of the Secondary Master Plan area through the Optimized Growth Plan presents an
opportunity to address the transportation needs and impacts of this development through land use policies
and system design that achieve an efficient, sustainable and environmentally sensitive multi-modal
transportation system. Land use regulations and incentives to encourage increased development density,
mixed-use, and pedestrian-supportive design will increase the options available for the movement of
people and goods and thereby lessen the reliance on automobiles. Transit-oriented development that
combines these land use principles to establish activity centers that are integrated with, or located within
convenient walking distance of, existing and planned transit services (such as CDTA's Bus Rapid Transit
system) will also make regional investments in transit more effective and further contribute to reduced
vehicle trips and vehicle-miles of travel (VMT).


The quality and character of the street layout and design also contribute to the effectiveness of a multi-
modal transportation system. The existing grid configuration of the street network within the master plan
area provides the basic framework for efficient multimodal accessibility and circulation to accommodate
the development of the Optimized Growth Plan. Adopting policies to support a concept of "Complete
Streets" to provide safe, efficient and appealing environments for walking, biking and transit will also
help to create a sustainable transportation system and enhance the vitality of the community.


The primary objective of the "Complete Streets" concept is to design the physical space within the public
right-of-way to support the human and economic activities of the surrounding uses in a way that considers
the needs of all users, including pedestrians, bicyclists, transit vehicles and users, and motorists, of all
ages and abilities. Elements of a "Complete Street" policy should aim to create a comprehensive,
connected network that is consistent with the context of the neighborhood and community. This policy
should also recognize that not all streets and contexts are the same, so that the solutions and design
elements can be flexible to balance user needs.       A "Complete Streets" policy should also include


Traffic Impact Study                                                       Clough Harbour & Associates LLP
Albany Convention Center                                                                          Page 48
performance standards with measurable outcomes that reflect the multi-modal components of the
transportation system and do not rely solely on the level-of-service metrics for vehicle traffic.


The integration of land use policies that support increased density and mixed-use with "Complete Streets"
policies that ensure that all users are appropriately accommodated by the transportation system can
achieve the following benefits:


        Reduced Congestion
        Improved Safety
        Improved Air Quality
        Improved Mobility and Accessibility
        Improved Health
        Facilitates Safe-Routes-to-School and other mobility programs oriented toward children

The land use and transportation design policies described above can also reduce the amount of parking
needed to support the new development within the Secondary Master Plan area. For example, increased
residential and employment density, and mixed-use development patterns, can reduce parking demand by
15-20 percent. Transit accessibility can also reduce parking requirements for housing and employment by
10-20 percent. Additional parking management strategies can further reduce the number of parking
spaces required to support the Optimum Growth Plan. Among the types of strategies that could be
employed are the following:


        Shared parking
        Establish parking maximums
        Flexible parking standards
        Unbundled Parking
        In-lieu parking fees



Shared Parking decreases the total number of parking spaces needed to support development by taking
advantage of the different peak parking demand characteristics of each land use component within a
mixed-use project. For example, offices and restaurants can often share the same pool of parking, which
reduces the overall number of spaces required to support these uses.


Parking Maximums place an upper limit on the supply of parking allowed at individual sites (as opposed
to requirements for minimum parking). This strategy is typically used in conjunction with an integrated
area-wide parking management program used to reduce excessive parking supply, which would otherwise
work against the objectives for a multi-modal transportation system.

Traffic Impact Study                                                        Clough Harbour & Associates LLP
Albany Convention Center                                                                           Page 49
Flexible parking standards allow for the parking needs of each development site to be considered in the
context of density, mixed-use, proximity to transit services and other remote parking.         With these
considerations, the on-site parking may be sized to be more frequently occupied fully, as long as overflow
parking is available nearby.


Unbundled parking is a strategy where the on-site parking is rented or sold separately from the building
space, so the occupants only pay for the amount of parking they want. In the case of offices, this could
also encourage employers to offer financial incentives (such as parking cash-out or transit benefits) to
employees for ride-sharing or transit alternatives to reduce parking need and vehicle trips.


In-Lieu parking fees are a mechanism where the City would collect fees from the site developers and
provide centrally located parking that is available to the development's tenants and visitors, rather than
having on-site parking. The fees would be established by the City and are generally based on the cost to
provide parking.


The implementation of parking management strategies for the Optimum Growth Plan should be
developed in coordination with the development community, Albany Parking Authority, City planners
and traffic engineers, and neighborhood groups.         The primary objective of these strategies is to
appropriately balance the parking required to service the new development and to achieve the broader
transportation goals to provide an efficient and safe multimodal system. Together, these principles of
smart-growth land development, "Complete Streets" design, and parking management will provide the
mechanisms for the City to achieve the Optimal Growth plan objectives and provide the transportation
system necessary to support this growth.




8.0     CONCLUSION AND RECOMMENDATIONS

The preceding analyses and evaluations have been conducted to identify the transportation impacts
associated with the development of the Albany Convention Center in downtown Albany, New York. This
study examined these impacts to traffic circulation, traffic operations, parking, transit and
pedestrian/bicycle components of the transportation system.




Traffic Impact Study                                                       Clough Harbour & Associates LLP
Albany Convention Center                                                                          Page 50
The following improvements and strategies have been identified to mitigate the impacts of the
Convention Center project on these various system components and to address the site requirements for
parking and access.

Traffic Circulation:
   1. Maintain access to 66 South Pearl Street parking garage and service loading dock.

    2. Improve Division Street-to-Dallius Street corridor for emergency services and evacuation.

Traffic Operations:
   1. Madison Avenue and Green Street: modify the signal control equipment and signal displays to
        provide a phase extension with protected left-turn arrow for southbound traffic on Green Street.

Parking:
   1. Construct new parking facilities as follows:
             Convention Center: 1,000 spaces
             Convention Center Hotel: 400 spaces
             Church Street/I-787 Remote Lots: 550 spaces
             APA Green-Hudson Garage Expansion: add new level for 210 parking spaces

    2. Leverage additional monthly subscriptions for dislocated onsite parking at APA's Green-Hudson
       Garage and Quackenbush Garage - 475 spaces. This will require coordination with APA and
       CDTA to establish incentives to compensate for added distance to primary employment
       destinations in the study area.

    3. Relocate state employee parking from surface lots beneath ESP Arterial adjacent to site to new
       parking facilities noted above. Convert this area to Convention Center uses.

Transit:
   1. Relocate CDTA Bus staging area beneath the Empire State Plaza Arterial from its present
        location north of Madison Avenue and west of Green Street to an area north of Madison Avenue
        between Broadway and Green Street. Provide an entrance-only access from Madison Avenue
        approximately 250 feet west of Broadway and an exit onto Liberty Street.

    2. Expand the relocated staging area to incorporate accommodations for displaced Greyhound
       parking and for Charter buses serving the Convention Center.

    3. Liberty Street Extension: Construct a new one-way roadway to connect Liberty Street to
       Broadway. This connector road will be restricted for buses only and will provide one-way
       (eastbound) travel. A gated control is recommended at the west end of the connecter to limit
       access to authorized buses only. A traffic signal is anticipated, if warranted, at the intersection of
       this connector road and Broadway. This signal will need to be interconnected to the signal at the
       intersection of Broadway and Water Street to provide coordinated operation. An alternative
       control strategy would be to link vehicle detection on the connector road with the signal at
       Broadway and Water Street to serve as a surrogate preemption. This improvement requires a
       "break-in-access" authorization of the NYSDOT and the FHWA.

    4. Contra-flow Bus Lane on Broadway: This improvement is contingent on implementation of the
        Liberty Street extension improvement, and is intended to address the circulation and access

Traffic Impact Study                                                       Clough Harbour & Associates LLP
Albany Convention Center                                                                          Page 51
        impacts of the Convention Center project on CDTA transit services. This improvement will
        involve widening of Broadway to establish the contra-flow lane and to install a median barrier to
        separate this lane from southbound traffic.

    5. Reconstruction of Broadway-Water Street-Quay Street Connector intersection to accommodate
       the northbound contra-flow bus lane and to create a conventional 4-legged intersection. This
       includes reconstruction of the eastbound intersection approach (Broadway) and removal of the
       landscaped island at the south leg of the intersection. Modify the alignment of the Water Street
       approach to the intersection to accommodate the new contra-flow northbound lane on the south
       leg of Broadway, including pavement, curb, sidewalk and landscaping. Replace the traffic signal
       equipment at this intersection to reflect the new geometry and traffic control/phasing.

    6. Widen Hamilton Street between Dallius Street and Liberty Street to provide two-way traffic
       circulation and on-street parking on both sides. Estimated width of pavement widening is 8 feet.
       Modify the curb radius at the southwest quadrant to facilitate bus right-turns from Hamilton
       Street onto Liberty Street (southbound).


Special Events:
Special events at the Convention Center may require the deployment of additional short-duration
transportation and parking management strategies to accommodate the traffic generated by these events.
These strategies involve a combination of traveler information, travel demand management and/or traffic
management tools and techniques. The Capital Region Traffic Management Task Force is an existing
consortium of transportation agencies and other stakeholders that provides the organizational framework
for developing logical and consistent event management plans, in conjunction with the event planners, to
provide safe and efficient transportation operations during these special events.



Optimal Growth Plan

The Convention Center is anticipated to stimulate additional development within a Secondary Master
Plan area that is generally within a ¾ mile radius of the Convention Center site. Development associated
with the Optimized Growth Plan for this Secondary Master Plan area would create 1.76 million square
feet of new commercial retail and office space and 5,600 residential units.


This induced development has the potential to generate a significant amount of new traffic within the
area. The transportation impacts and needs of this development can be addressed by applying land use
policies and system design that achieve an efficient, sustainable and environmentally sensitive multi-
modal transportation system.     Land use regulations and incentives are recommended to encourage
increased development density, mixed-use, and pedestrian-supportive design to increase the options
available for the movement of people and goods and thereby lessen the reliance on automobiles. Transit-


Traffic Impact Study                                                          Clough Harbour & Associates LLP
Albany Convention Center                                                                             Page 52
oriented development that combines these land use principles to establish activity centers that are
integrated with, or located within convenient walking distance of, transit services will also make regional
investments in transit more effective and further contribute to reduced vehicle trips and vehicle-miles of
travel (VMT).


The quality and character of the street layout and design also contribute to the effectiveness of a multi-
modal transportation system. Adopting policies to support a concept of "Complete Streets" to provide
safe, efficient and appealing environments for walking, biking and transit will also help to create a
sustainable transportation system and enhance the vitality of the community.


These land use and transportation design policies can also reduce the amount of parking needed to support
the new development within the Secondary Master Plan area. Additional parking management strategies
can further reduce the number of parking spaces required to support the Optimum Growth Plan. Among
the types of strategies that could be employed are the following:


        Shared parking
        Establish parking maximums
        Flexible parking standards
        Unbundled Parking
        In-lieu parking fees



The implementation of parking management strategies for the Optimum Growth Plan should be
developed in coordination with the development community, Albany Parking Authority, City planners
and traffic engineers, and neighborhood groups.        The primary objective of these strategies is to
appropriately balance the parking required to service the new development and to achieve the broader
transportation goals to provide an efficient and safe multi-modal system. Together, these principles of
smart-growth land development, "Complete Streets" design, and parking management will provide the
mechanisms for the City to achieve the Optimal Growth plan objectives and provide the transportation
system necessary to support this growth.

    COMPLETED BY:   J. Kinley                                                     1      6     4    3    3     2     0    0     0     1    3    1     0
     CHECKED BY:    D Kahlbaugh                                                  SHEET #:       4       OF      4
   PROJECT NAME:    Albany Convention Center                                          DATE:                    Dec-07
PROJECT LOCATION:   Albany, NY                                                SUBJECT:        Diverted Traffic from Displaced Parking



Existing Parking in Area:                720      Surface Parking on ACC Site
                                         730      OGS Employee Parking under ESP Arterial
                                         900      APA Green-Hudson Garage
                                         135      Key Bank Parking
                                        2485      Total Spaces


AM Peak Hour
                                                                                                                         Volume           Distribution %

               1,750 trips                 = 0.70 trips per parking space                               Entering              1,150            0.66
      2,485 existing parking spaces                                                                      Exiting               600             0.34
                                                                                                             Total            1,750




PM Peak Hour
                                                                                                                         Volume           Distribution %

               1,760 trips                 =      0.71 trips per parking space                          Entering               535             0.30
      2,485 existing parking spaces                                                                      Exiting              1,225            0.70
                                                                                                             Total            1,760




             ACC will remove 1,450 spaces from area = 58% reduction of existing volumes


             Assumption: Parking accumulates over a 3-hour AM commuter period
                                Estimated Peak-hour trip rate per parking space = 0.50 trips


             2,485 x 0.50 =         1,240 trips generated by parking during peak hour
             1,750 - 1,240 =        510 trips thru traffic during peak hour
             1,240 trips x 0.58 =        719 trips reduced from area as a result of parking displacement


     Say:    720 entering trips will divert from area in AM Peak due to parking displacement
             720 exiting trips will divert from area in PM Peak due to parking displacement

    COMPLETED BY:   S. Bowman                                               1      6     4    3     3     2     0    0     0    1    3    1   0

   PROJECT NAME:    Albany Convention Center                                    DATE:                   1/22/2008
PROJECT LOCATION:   Albany, NY                                            SUBJECT:      Optimized Growth Plan - Trip Generation



Optimized Growth Plan - Design Year 2020


Residential: 5,600 Total Units                          Assumption:       60% Condominium/Townhouse
                                                                          40% Apartments


Apartments          ITE LUC 220                         5,600 x 0.40 = 2,240 units


AM Peak Hour:                        Method 1: Avg Trip Rate              2,240 x 0.51 = 1,142 trips


                                     Method 2: Equation*                  2,240/10 = 224 avg units per group
                                                                          T= 10 [0.49(224) + 3.73]
                                                                          T= 10 x 113.49
                                                                          T = 1,135 trips                           say:       1,150 trips


                                                                                              Enter:           1,150 x 0.20 =       230
                                                                                                  Exit:        1,150 x 0.80 =       920

                                     Method 2: Equation*                  2,240/10 = 224 avg units per group

                                                                          T= 10 x 140.85

                                                                                                  Exit:        1,400 x 0.35 =       490

Total units are divided into subgroups to correlate to the average development size of the ITE data samples.

       APPENDIX C
LEVEL OF SERVICE CRITERIA
From the Highway Capacity Manual 2000 published by the Transportation Research Board:

Signalized Intersections

                 LOS CRITERIA FOR SIGNALIZED INTERSECTIONS
                       LOS             Control Delay per Vehicle (s/veh)*
                        A                           10
                        B                           10-20
                        C                           20-35
                        D                           35-55
                        E                           55-80
                        F                           80
               Highway Capacity Manual 2000
               * s/veh = seconds per vehicle



LOS A describes operations with low control delay, up to 10 s/veh. This LOS occurs
when progression is extremely favorable and most vehicles arrive during the green
phase. Most vehicles do not stop at all. Short cycle lengths may tend to contribute to
low delay values.

LOS B describes operations with control delay greater than 10 and up to 20 s/veh. This
level generally occurs with good progression, short cycle lengths, or both. More vehicles
stop than with LOS A, causing higher levels of delay.

LOS C describes operations with control delay greater than 20 and up to 35 s/veh.
These higher delays may result from only fair progression, longer cycle lengths, or both.
Individual cycle failures may begin to appear at this level. Cycle failure occurs when a
green phase does not serve queued vehicles, and overflows occur. The number of
vehicles stopping is significant at this level, though many still pass through the
intersection without stopping.

LOS D describes operations with control delay greater than 35 and up to 55 s/veh. At
LOS D, the influence of congestion becomes more noticeable. Longer delays may result
from some combination of unfavorable progression, long cycle lengths, or high volume-
to-capacity (v/c) ratios. Many vehicles stop, and the proportion of vehicles not stopping
declines. Individual cycle failures are noticeable.

LOS E describes operations with control delay greater than 55 and up to 80 s/veh.
These high delay values generally indicate poor progression, long cycle lengths, and
high v/c ratios. Individual cycle failures are frequent.

LOS F describes operations with delay in excess of 80.0 s/veh. This level, considered
unacceptable to most drivers, often occurs with over-saturation, that is, when arrival flow
rates exceed the capacity of lane groups. It may also occur at high v/c ratios with many
individual cycle failures. Poor progression and long cycle lengths may also be contribute
significantly to high delay levels. Often, vehicles do not pass through the intersection in
one signal cycle.
Unsignalized Intersections

The level of service criteria for an unsignalized intersection differs from that of a
signalized intersection because of the expectation that signalized intersections
encounter more traffic and therefore greater delays. The thresholds for the levels of
service of unsignalized intersections are as follows:

              LOS CRITERIA FOR UNSIGNALIZED INTERSECTIONS
                      LOS              Control Delay per Vehicle (s/veh)
                       A                           10
                       B                           10-15
                       C                           15-25
                       D                           25-35
                       E                           35-50
                       F                           50
              Highway Capacity Manual 2000
              * s/veh = seconds per vehicle
